text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This transmittal reissues existing procedures. Minor editorial changes have been made throughout this IRM. Website addresses, legal references, and IRM references were reviewed and updated as necessary. Other signiﬁcant changes to this IRM include the following:
Description of Changes
Inserted new section for Internal Controls as required by IRM
Clariﬁed the information available on the Technical Services Shar
oint site.
Included information regarding restitution-based as- sessment (RBA) cases related to the respective status codes.
Updated the timeframe for the initial screening of incoming cases and their statute of limitations.
Clariﬁed the appropriate status code to use when returning cases to the ﬁeld.
Revised the location for storing copies of Form
which are retained in Technical Services pending the response from the ﬁeld.
Clariﬁed language to properly identify and speak to the initial presumptive period for the taxpayer.
Removed detailed procedures of the Fraud and Grand Jury Suspense program and moved to IRM

Revised summary paragraph to clarify the role of the reviewer or coordinator assigned to this program and updated references. Clariﬁed roles and titles of the fraud coordinator and Department of Justice (DOJ).

Reference Description of Changes IRM Added paragraph to reference procedures for 4.8.2.11.4.1(3) tracking time applied and actions taken on the activity record. IRM Updated debtor’s liability limit for Chapter 11 small 4.8.2.11.4.2.3 business cases. IRM Included clariﬁcation regarding cases with six 4.8.2.11.4.8.8(3) months or less remaining on the statute. IRM Re-structured sub-section to organize by steps in 4.8.2.11.4.8.15 the procedures for cases when only one spouse is in bankruptcy and to include the MFT 31 mirroring process. IRM Added paragraph to ensure MFT 31 accounts are 4.8.2.11.4.8.15.4 mirrored properly after being established. IRM 4.8.2.11.4 Incorporated Interim Guidance SBSE-04-0316-0005 dated March 17, 2016 throughout sub-section. IRM Added checksheet requirement to be completed 4.8.2.11.4.9 prior to placing a case into bankruptcy suspense. IRM Added project codes and tracking codes to be 4.8.2.11.4.9.3 included on cases if not already reﬂected on AIMS. IRM Added requirement for managers to complete 4.8.2.11.4.9.4 checksheet when reviewing and approving statute of limitations updates. Also included Caution to ensure the non-bankrupt spouse assessment is made prior to updating the statute to “KK”. IRM Updated the tracking of monthly PACER checks and 4.8.2.11.4.9.6 research on the new checksheet. IRM Added requirement for managers to monitor action 4.8.2.11.4.9.7 dates and the use of Review Type 48 on cases throughout the suspense process. IRM Updated to reﬂect Review Type 48 to be used on 4.8.2.11.4.10 cases throughout the suspense process and to reﬂect the new exhibit for calculating the statute of limitations. IRM Updated section title to clarify the types of cases it 4.8.2.11.4.10.1 refers to. IRM New sub section added to address cases with a 4.8.2.11.4.10.2 split spousal assessment required. IRM Clariﬁed actions that need to be veriﬁed before 4.8.2.11.5.1 placing a case into bankruptcy suspense. Exhibit 4.8.2-1 Updated to include codes related to Criminal Resti- tution

Reference Description of Changes Fraud Exhibits Removed exhibits related to the Fraud and Grand Jury Suspense program and moved to IRM 4.8.11. (i.e., Exhibits numbered three through nine) Exhibit 4.8.2-3 Re-numbered exhibit after exhibits related to Fraud and Exhibit and Grand Jury Suspense were moved. 4.8.2-4 Exhibit 4.8.2-5 Re-numbered exhibit after exhibits related to Fraud and Grand Jury Suspense were moved. Exhibit 4.8.2-7 New exhibit for the bankruptcy suspense review checksheet. Exhibit 4.8.2-8 New exhibit for the bankruptcy suspense manage- rial checksheet.

) Purpose. This IRM section describes the procedures for processing cases ﬂow through Technical Services. Speciﬁcally, IRM

outlines the and and criteria for the following: a. Returning cases to ﬁeld examination for re-work, b. Applying of the appropriate coding for cases on ERCS to monitor and control inventory and statutes of limitation, and c. Monitoring of suspense programs in Technical Services. (
) Audience. These procedures apply to Technical Services employees to the various programs discussed in this IRM. (
) Policy Owner. The Technical Services office is under Examination Field Examination. (

) Program Owner. Technical Services is the program office responsible for pro- cessing and closing cases which include the following (but not limited to): a. Mandatory review cases b. Unagreed cases requiring a statutory notice of deﬁciency (SNOD) c. Protested cases closing to Appeals d. Hobby Loss suspense cases e. Bankruptcy suspense cases f. Form
suspense cases (
) Contact Information. To recommend changes or make any other suggestions this IRM section, e-mail the author. (
) The Technical Services area was established in

when the various business units such as SB/SE, LB&I, W&I were realigned and their Examination and Collection areas were aligned separately. As such, Services serves as the overall closing function for Field Examination cases the various situations as listed in IRM
) By law, the Service has the authority to make the appropriate assessments once the examination is completed and the taxpayer has been appropriately notiﬁed of the audit results. IRM

details the procedures to be followed when unagreed cases are closed from Field Examination to ensure the er’s rights have been protected as well as the case inventory while in Services is properly monitored and statutes are protected. Also, by law, the taxpayer is afforded certain rights when dealing with bankruptcy, hobby loss issues, Form
litigation, etc. thus requiring the suspense programs in Technical Services to monitor the outcome of said issues and to complete case processing as appropriate. (
) The Bankruptcy Code provides an opportunity to the taxpayer to ﬁle for debt relief via a bankruptcy petition to the U.S. Bankruptcy Court. These are found in Title
of the United States Code. The Bankruptcy Reform Act
(BRA
) and the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protec- tion Act of

(BAPCPA) provided signiﬁcant revisions to the Bankruptcy Code. The Insolvency section of the Collection function of the SB/SE division of the Service is responsible for the coordination of the bankruptcy case for each taxpayer. (

) The Director, Examination - Technical Services is the executive the inventory control and case processing in Technical Services. The responsibilities are as outlined below in this IRM. (
) Audience - The employees responsible for taking action or who require knowledge about the program, process or activity. (

) Automatic stay - the stay that arises by operation of law when a petition is ﬁled. It prohibits certain acts against the debtor, the debtor’s property, and property of the estate. Since the automatic stay provision amended in
and again in
, the scope of the automatic stay on when the bankruptcy petition was ﬁled. (
) Bankruptcy coordinator - the Technical Services revenue agent assigned complete the various required procedures for the bankruptcy suspense program outlined in this chapter. (
) Collateral record - the record maintained on ERCS only for monitoring issues that are not controlled on AIMS. (
) Form
, Reviewer’s Report - document that is used by the reviewer outline the necessary revisions and / or re-work needed on a case when returned to Field Examination. (
) Review type - the respective code placed on a case to identify the type inventory in which it is associated (e.g., SNOD, bankruptcy, etc.) (
) Suspense cases - cases that must be held until certain actions are before the ﬁnal processing can be completed. (
) Suspense type - the respective code placed on a case that gives the timeframe / action date for which the case is to be completed. (

Mathematical, technical, managerial or procedural errors or omissions that require additional consideration or development are usually returned to the re- sponsible group when it cannot be perfected by the reviewer.
Technical (
) Form

should clearly communicate the corrective action required, ing in an objective understandable manner the error, or if a commendatory observation, a clear explanation describing how the examiner’s actions were superior. (

) Only an objective discussion of the deﬁciencies should be addressed. Avoid subjective commentary unless the conclusion reached by the examiner is not supported by the facts developed in the case ﬁle. Conclusively support obser- vations as they relate to the quality attributes. (
) Strive to choose words and phrases that are constructive in nature and dem- onstrate an interest in helping the examiner. (

) Observation Report: The observation report is used to advise management areas requiring attention or exceptionally good performance of an examiner. (Form There are two types of observation reports based on who the report is sent of Reports a. Commendatory, Managerial, or Other: Observation reports are sent to the area ﬁeld territory manager once the report is signed by the TS group manager. ) The correction of the error is favorable to the taxpayer. Corrections that are in the taxpayer’s favor (less tax due or larger refund) must be made. Every effort should be made to waive errors within the scope of authority. However, taxpayers should not be harmed by Service errors. If correcting an error reduces the taxpayer’s liability or increase the taxpayer’s refund, then the cor- rection will be made without regard to the dollar amount. The case should be returned to the examiner for correction. However, if the error can be readily corrected by TS, such action should be taken to close the case expeditiously.

When placing a case in suspense always: a. Verify the statutes are properly protected. There must be at least one left on the statute. If there is an inadequate amount of time left on the statute, return the case to the originating group with the instruction to secure a statute extension or otherwise protect the statute. b. Verify any partial agreements, if applicable, have been assessed by the examiner. If not, the case should be returned to the examiner to the appropriate actions. , the ﬁrst two pages of the RAR and the necessary agreement form should be faxed to the appropriate CCP site for immediate assessment. CCP will fax a copy of Form

with a screen print of IDRS showing “Request Completed” back to TS to indicate the partial assessment was completed. c. Verify the issues in the case qualify the case for suspension. Advise group that if the issues that cannot be suspended are not resolved, the case may not be placed in suspense. If a partial agreement cannot be secured and the taxpayer does not exercise their right to an appeal, a notice of deﬁciency will need to be issued on all issues. d. Verify the case has been developed to the fullest extent possible. A revenue agent report (RAR) should be in the case ﬁle listing the adjust- ments being suspended. Once it is determined the case can be placed into suspense, update the case on ERCS and AIMS to the correct status code. If there are two or more dismissals or anything other than a discharge that are less than a year from the current bankruptcy ﬁling, there would be no automatic stay. For a joint return, are both taxpayers in bankruptcy? If not, there should be MFT 31 accounts established for both taxpayers and the non-bankrupt spouse should have a fully posted assessment before changing the statute to “KK”. 3. Did the bankruptcy coordinator document the automatic stay is in pace? a. Does the PACER summary page show the taxpayer ﬁled another bankruptcy within 12 months of a previously dismissed bankruptcy? If yes, have the serial rules been considered? b. Are there any ﬂags reﬂected on the docket (usually found on the top right of the docket) that should be considered? (e.g., DISCHDENIED, NODISCH, NODIS, CLOSED, DISMISSED, WAIVED) If any exist, then make sure the coordinator has considered and made a determination that the automatic stay is still in place. c. Was the taxpayer in bankruptcy any time during the Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency 90 / 150 day period? If not, then the case should not be held in suspense.
